subject: Law
title: Child Soldiers Under International Law
description: Learn Child Soldiers Under International Law in one minute.

hook.text: A 12-year-old carries an AK-47 into battle. He didn't choose to fight. Recruiting him was a war crime.

buildup.text: International law prohibits recruiting or using children under 15 in armed conflict. Many treaties set the bar at 18.

discovery.text: The Rome Statute classifies using child soldiers as a war crime, punishable by the ICC.

twist.text: Thomas Lubanga was the ICC's first convictionâ€”for enlisting child soldiers in the Democratic Republic of Congo.

climax.text: An estimated 250,000 child soldiers are active today. The law exists; enforcement and rehabilitation lag behind.

punchline.text: Children belong in schools, not battlefields. The law agrees.

quiz.question: Who was the ICC's first person convicted of using child soldiers?
